transcript:
Therapist: Liam, you mentioned that you've been relying on sleep as your primary coping mechanism. I'm wondering if there are any other strategies you've tried in the past to manage your depression, even if they weren't entirely effective.

Patient: Well, I've always enjoyed writing, so sometimes I try to express my feelings through journaling or working on my language learning blog. It helps a little, but it's hard to stay motivated when I'm feeling really low.

Therapist: Writing can be a great outlet for processing emotions and gaining insights into your thoughts and experiences. It's good that you've found some relief in that activity. Aside from your creative pursuits, have you ever sought professional help for your depression before?

Patient: No, I haven't. My family has always been a bit skeptical about therapy, and I guess I just never thought it was for me. But I'm starting to realize that I need more support than I can get from my family and friends alone.

Therapist: It takes courage to recognize when you need additional support and to reach out for help. I'm glad you've taken this step towards prioritizing your mental health. Speaking of your family and friends, how would you describe your current support system?

Patient: My family is generally supportive, but they don't really understand what I'm going through. My mom is probably the most understanding, but even she can be a bit dismissive of my feelings sometimes. As for my friends, I have a few close friends from my doctoral program, but they live in different cities now, so it's hard to stay connected.

Therapist: It sounds like you have some support, but there might be a gap in terms of understanding and emotional connection. Building a strong support system is crucial when dealing with depression. In our work together, we can explore ways to strengthen your existing relationships and potentially expand your support network.

Patient: That would be great. I know I need to work on opening up more to the people in my life, but it's just so hard sometimes.

Therapist: It's understandable that opening up can be challenging, especially when you're already feeling vulnerable. We can work on developing strategies to help you communicate your needs and feelings more effectively with your loved ones.

Patient: I think that would be really helpful. I just want to feel less alone in this struggle.

Therapist: You're not alone, Liam. I'm here to support you, and together, we'll work on building a stronger support system and developing healthier coping mechanisms. As we continue our sessions, we'll dive deeper into the thoughts and beliefs that may be contributing to your depression and explore ways to challenge and reframe them.

Patient: I'm looking forward to making some progress and starting to feel better. It's been a long time since I've felt like myself.
